Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “Can you come over? I really need you.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. I grabbed my keys, heart pounding, already picturing her tear-streaked face. As I stepped outside, I noticed the flyer taped to my door—today was the last day to vote on the new zoning law that would change our block forever. The polling place was just a few blocks away, but it closed in two hours. I’d promised myself I’d always participate, that I’d never take my responsibilities as a citizen lightly. But my sister was waiting, probably pacing her living room, counting on me to be there for her like I always had. I stood on the sidewalk, torn between the pull of family and the weight of civic duty, feeling the minutes slip away as I tried to decide which role I owed more in this moment.
